sn45.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn45.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn45.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn45.1:2.1.pli: “Avijjā, bhikkhave, pubbaṅgamā akusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā, anvadeva ahirikaṃ anottappaṃ.
sn45.1:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, ignorance precedes the attainment of unskillful qualities, with lack of conscience and prudence following along.

sn45.1:2.2.eng: An ignoramus, sunk in ignorance, produces wrong view.

sn45.1:3.1.pli: Vijjā ca kho, bhikkhave, pubbaṅgamā kusalānaṃ dhammānaṃ samāpattiyā, anvadeva hirottappaṃ.
sn45.1:3.1.eng: Knowledge precedes the attainment of skillful qualities, with conscience and prudence following along.

sn45.1:3.2.eng: A sage, firm in knowledge, produces right view.

sn45.10:1.2.pli: Atha kho nandiyo paribbājako yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṃ sammodi.
sn45.10:1.2.eng: Then the wanderer Nandiya went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

sn45.10:1.3.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho nandiyo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn45.10:1.3.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, and said to the Buddha:

sn45.10:1.4.pli: “kati nu kho, bho gotama, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā nibbānaṅgamā honti nibbānaparāyanā nibbānapariyosānā”ti?
sn45.10:1.4.eng: “Mister Gotama, how many things, when developed and cultivated, have extinguishment as their target, destination, and culmination?”

sn45.10:2.1.pli: “Aṭṭhime kho, nandiya, dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā nibbānaṅgamā honti nibbānaparāyanā nibbānapariyosānā.
sn45.10:2.1.eng: “These eight things, when developed and cultivated, have extinguishment as their target, destination, and culmination.

sn45.10:2.3.eng: They are: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.10:2.4.pli: Ime kho, nandiya, aṭṭha dhammā bhāvitā bahulīkatā nibbānaṅgamā honti nibbānaparāyanā nibbānapariyosānā”ti.
sn45.10:2.4.eng: These eight things, when developed and cultivated, have extinguishment as their target, destination, and culmination.”

sn45.10:2.5.pli: Evaṃ vutte, nandiyo paribbājako bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn45.10:2.5.eng: When he said this, the wanderer Nandiya said to the Buddha,

sn45.10:2.7.pli: upāsakaṃ maṃ bhavaṃ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṃ saraṇaṃ gatan”ti.
sn45.10:2.7.eng: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”

sn45.103:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
sn45.103:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

sn45.103:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn45.103:1.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn45.103:1.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?
sn45.103:1.3.eng: And how does a mendicant who develops the noble eightfold path slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?

sn45.103:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṃ dosavinayapariyosānaṃ mohavinayapariyosānaṃ …pe… sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti rāgavinayapariyosānaṃ dosavinayapariyosānaṃ mohavinayapariyosānaṃ.
sn45.103:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which culminate in the removal of greed, hate, and delusion.

sn45.103:1.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn45.103:1.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”

sn45.11:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I wish to go on retreat for a fortnight.

sn45.11:1.3.pli: Namhi kenaci upasaṅkamitabbo, aññatra ekena piṇḍapātanīhārakenā”ti.
sn45.11:1.3.eng: No-one should approach me, except for the one who brings my almsfood.”

sn45.11:1.4.pli: “Evaṃ, bhante”ti kho te bhikkhū bhagavato paṭissutvā nāssudha koci bhagavantaṃ upasaṅkamati, aññatra ekena piṇḍapātanīhārakena.
sn45.11:1.4.eng: “Yes, sir,” replied those mendicants. And no-one approached him, except for the one who brought the almsfood.

sn45.11:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā tassa aḍḍhamāsassa accayena paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito bhikkhū āmantesi:
sn45.11:2.1.eng: Then after a fortnight had passed, the Buddha came out of retreat and addressed the mendicants:

sn45.11:2.2.pli: “yena svāhaṃ, bhikkhave, vihārena paṭhamābhisambuddho viharāmi, tassa padesena vihāsiṃ.
sn45.11:2.2.eng: “Mendicants, I’ve been practicing part of the meditation I practiced when I was first awakened.

sn45.11:2.4.eng: there’s feeling conditioned by wrong view

sn45.11:2.5.eng: and feeling conditioned by right view. …

sn45.11:2.6.eng: There’s feeling conditioned by wrong immersion,

sn45.11:2.7.eng: and feeling conditioned by right immersion.

sn45.11:2.11.pli: chando ca avūpasanto hoti, vitakko ca avūpasanto hoti, saññā ca avūpasantā hoti, tappaccayāpi vedayitaṃ;
sn45.11:2.11.eng: As long as desire, thought, and perception are not stilled, there is feeling conditioned by that.

sn45.11:2.12.pli: chando ca vūpasanto hoti, vitakko ca vūpasanto hoti, saññā ca vūpasantā hoti, tappaccayāpi vedayitaṃ;
sn45.11:2.12.eng: When desire, thought, and perception are stilled, there is feeling conditioned by that.

sn45.11:2.13.pli: appattassa pattiyā atthi āyāmaṃ, tasmimpi ṭhāne anuppatte tappaccayāpi vedayitan’”ti.
sn45.11:2.13.eng: There is effort to attain the unattained. When that state has been attained, there is also feeling conditioned by that.”

sn45.127:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
sn45.127:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east.

sn45.127:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.
sn45.127:1.2.eng: In the same way, a mendicant who develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn45.127:1.3.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?
sn45.127:1.3.eng: And how does a mendicant who develops the noble eightfold path slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?

sn45.127:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti nibbānaninnaṃ nibbānapoṇaṃ nibbānapabbhāraṃ …pe… sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti nibbānaninnaṃ nibbānapoṇaṃ nibbānapabbhāraṃ.
sn45.127:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn45.127:1.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn45.127:1.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”

sn45.128-132:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yamunā nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;
sn45.128-132:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Yamunā river slants, slopes, and inclines to the east. …”

sn45.128-132:1.3.pli: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, aciravatī nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;

sn45.128-132:1.5.pli: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, sarabhū nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;

sn45.128-132:1.7.pli: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, mahī nadī pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;

sn45.128-132:1.9.pli: seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, yā kācimā mahānadiyo, seyyathidaṃ—

sn45.128-132:1.10.pli: gaṅgā, yamunā, aciravatī, sarabhū, mahī, sabbā tā pācīnaninnā pācīnapoṇā pācīnapabbhārā;

sn45.128-132:1.11.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.

sn45.128-132:1.12.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro?

sn45.128-132:1.13.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti nibbānaninnaṃ nibbānapoṇaṃ nibbānapabbhāraṃ …pe… sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti nibbānaninnaṃ nibbānapoṇaṃ nibbānapabbhāraṃ.

sn45.128-132:1.14.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.

sn45.13:1.2.pli: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami …pe… ekamantaṃ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
sn45.13:1.2.eng: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha … and asked him,

sn45.13:1.3.eng: “Sir, they speak of the one called ‘a trainee’.

sn45.13:1.4.pli: Kittāvatā nu kho, bhante, sekkho hotī”ti?

sn45.13:2.1.pli: “Idha, bhikkhu, sekkhāya sammādiṭṭhiyā samannāgato hoti …pe… sekkhena sammāsamādhinā samannāgato hoti.
sn45.13:2.1.eng: “Mendicant, it’s someone who has a trainee’s right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

sn45.13:2.2.eng: That’s how a trainee is defined.”

sn45.133:1.1.pli: “Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, gaṅgā nadī samuddaninnā samuddapoṇā samuddapabbhārā;
sn45.133:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, the Ganges river slants, slopes, and inclines to the ocean.

sn45.133:1.2.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro.

sn45.133:1.3.eng: And how does a mendicant who develops the noble eightfold path slant, slope, and incline to extinguishment?

sn45.133:1.4.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sammādiṭṭhiṃ bhāveti nibbānaninnaṃ nibbānapoṇaṃ nibbānapabbhāraṃ …pe… sammāsamādhiṃ bhāveti nibbānaninnaṃ nibbānapoṇaṃ nibbānapabbhāraṃ.
sn45.133:1.4.eng: It’s when a mendicant develops right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion, which slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.

sn45.133:1.5.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bhāvento ariyaṃ aṭṭhaṅgikaṃ maggaṃ bahulīkaronto nibbānaninno hoti nibbānapoṇo nibbānapabbhāro”ti.
sn45.133:1.5.eng: That’s how a mendicant who develops and cultivates the noble eightfold path slants, slopes, and inclines to extinguishment.”
